questions.text: 1. Patients of Neurofibromatosis type 1 present with different extent of clinical features despite the same genetic defect. Which of the following best describes the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Patients presenting with different extents of clinical features despite having the same genetic defect is due to the phenomenon of variable expressivity

Variable expressivity refers to a similar genotype but a varying phenotype. The trait will be present in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among individuals. It is a feature of autosomal dominant disorders. Ex:- varying severity of disease with NF1 mutation (neurofibromatosis).

Other options

Option B: Anticipation refers to an earlier onset of disease in successive generations in a pedigree. It is seen in Huntington's disease, myotonic dystrophy, and fragile X syndrome.

 Option C: Incomplete penetrance refers to variations in penetrance and expressivity of clinical features. Not all individuals who inherit the mutant gene show a mutant phenotype. It is a feature of autosomal dominant disorders.   

Option D: A single mutant gene producing multiple end-organ defects is termed pleiotropism.

For example, in sickle-cell anemia, the point mutation in the gene not only predisposes the red blood cells to hemolysis but can also block the vessels. This leads to splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone changes. The numerous differing end-organ derangements are all related to the primary defect in hemoglobin synthesis.

questions.text: 2. A 12-year-old boy was diagnosed with Kearns-Sayre syndrome. Which of his relatives could be affected by the same disease?
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern of Kearns-Sayre syndrome is mitochondrial inheritance, therefore his sister could be affected with the disease.

As the disease is only transmitted from mother to all offsprings, he neither could transmit the disease to his offsprings, be it male or female child nor could he have got it from his father.

Kearns-Sayre syndrome clinical features :

* Ophthalmoplegia

* Pigmentory retinopathy

* Cardiomyopathy

Mitochondrial inheritance:

* Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome.

* Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.

* Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.

questions.text: 3. A pathologist is examining the peripheral smear of a patient with suspected leukemia. All of the following features are suggestive of a myeloblast except:
questions.solution:
Pelger-Huet anomaly is not a feature of myeloblasts. Auer rods and Phi bodies are considered pathognomonic of AML.

Myeloblasts have the following characteristics as shown in the following image:

* Large, uniform population of cells

* Prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow in the image)

* Primary cytoplasmic granules

* Auer rods - needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by fusion of lysosomes (black arrow)

* Phi-bodies - fusiform or spindle-shaped rods similar to Auer rods that require special stains for hydroperoxidases

* Pseudo-Chediak-Higashi syndrome - Giant lysosomes forming intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies



Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to neutrophils with bilobed nuclei that occur as a benign, inherited condition. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to an acquired defect seen in CML, myelodysplastic syndrome. 

Note: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with abnormal lysosomal trafficking (LYST gene). Presents with oculocutaneous albinism and immunodeficiency.

questions.text: 6. Which of the following testicular tumors are correctly matched with the corresponding tumor markers?
questions.solution:
Embryonal carcinomas are OCT3/4 +ve, cytokeratin +ve, KIT -ve, and podoplanin -ve.

Tumor markers are substances (eg. enzymes, antigens) that are detectable in the blood or tissue pathology of cancer patients. They can aid in tumor diagnosis, monitoring treatment response, and detecting cancer recurrence. Tumor markers immunohistochemistry of testicular tumors are particularly helpful in aiding diagnosis. 

Embryonal carcinomas on immunohistochemistry stain positive for OCT3/4 and cytokeratin. They are negative for KIT and podoplanin (option D). 

Seminomas on immunohistochemistry stain positive for OCT3/4, KIT, and podoplanin (option C). They stain negative for cytokeratin (option A).

questions.text: 8. A researcher in pathology is conducting experiments related to chemical carcinogenesis. Which of the following chemical carcinogens requires metabolic activation for conversion into active carcinogens?
questions.solution:
Benzidine requires metabolic activation for conversion into an active carcinogen.

All initiating chemical carcinogens are highly reactive electrophiles that may target the DNA, RNA, or proteins. Initiation occurs after cells are exposed to a sufficient dose of a carcinogen. It causes DNA mutations, which are passed on to daughter cells. Chemicals that can cause the initiation of carcinogenesis are of two types:

* Direct-acting carcinogens require no metabolic conversion to become carcinogenic. Most are weak carcinogens, but some are important because they are cancer chemotherapeutic drugs. Examples include:

* Dimethyl sulfate (Option C)

* Nitrosurea (Option D)

* Chlorambucil(Option B)

* Cyclophosphamide

* Dimethylcarbamyl chloride

* Indirect-acting carcinogens or procarcinogens are chemicals that require metabolic conversion to become active carcinogens. The carcinogenic product of metabolism is called an ultimate carcinogen. Examples include:

* Benzanthracene

* Benzopyrene

* β-naphthylamine

* Benzidine

* Natural plant and microbial products like aflatoxin B1, griseofulvin, betel nuts

* Nitrosamines and amides

* Vinyl chloride, nickel, chromium

questions.text: 9. A 7-year-old boy with frequent nosebleeds is brought to the OPD for a routine check-up. He has a history of excessive bleeding during a dental procedure that he underwent recently. Which factor responsible for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall is defective?
questions.solution:
The factor responsible for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall that is defective in this child is von Willebrand factor (vWF).

Platelet adhesion is mediated by interactions between the platelet surface receptor glycoprotein Ib -GpIb and vWF in the subendothelial matrix. Endothelial injury exposes vWF and causes the adhesion of platelets by the GpIb receptor. ADP binding to ADP receptors (Option B) induces conformational changes in platelets. This change in glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (Option C) that occurs with platelet activation allows it to bind to fibrinogen, which leads to aggregation of platelets to each other and not to the endothelium.

The defect in vWF causes von Willebrand disease. The most common presenting symptoms are spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes (epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds, or menorrhagia with a normal platelet count.

Factor VIII is found bound to the von Willebrand factor (vWF)  in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolonged aPTT in this disease (Option A). Prolonged bleeding time is due to abnormal platelet-mediated hemostasis.

questions.text: 10. In Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) all of the following are true except?

choices.text: Type 2 occurs 5 to 14 days after therapy begins
Direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin is seen in type 1
Type 1 is caused by antibodies that recognise complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4

questions.solution:
Type 2 of HIT is caused by antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4.

Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a life-threatening complication of heparin. It usually occurs within 3-5 days of starting unfractionated or low molecular weight (LMW) heparin. Thrombocytopenia occurs in about 5% of persons receiving heparin and is of two types:

* Type I thrombocytopenia

* Occurs rapidly after the onset of therapy.

* More common of the two types(Option A)

* It most likely results from a direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin.(Option C)

* Resolves spontaneously

* Type II thrombocytopenia is

* Less common

* It occurs 5 to 14 days after therapy begins.(Option B)

* It often leads to life-threatening venous and arterial thrombosis.

* It is caused by antibodies that recognize complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4, which is a normal component of platelet granules.

* Heparin should be discontinued and replaced with other non-heparin anticoagulants.

questions.text: 12. What is the pathological mechanism responsible for the RBC shape shown in this peripheral smear?

choices.text: Mutations in genes encoding for ankyrin, spectrin, and band proteins
Acquired mutation in the PIGA gene
Point mutation in the beta-globin gene

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows bite cells or degmacytes, characteristically associated with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency), an X-linked recessive condition.

Reduced glutathione is required to protect the cells against oxidant injury. This glutathione is kept in a reduced state by NADPH. Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is required to generate NADPH while oxidizing glucose-6-phosphate. G6PD deficiency results in reduced levels of NADPH which subsequently reduces the level of reduced glutathione. Therefore, in conditions like infections, which increase the production of oxygen free radicals, the red blood cells are damaged. 

Other triggers that lead to oxidative stress are drugs like sulphonamides, antimalarials, and fava beans.

Increased oxidative damage to RBCs leads to the formation of denatured precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These bodies can damage the RBC membrane leading to intravascular hemolysis. Additionally, when such RBCs pass through the splenic cords, macrophages pluck out these precipitates, giving them the characteristic appearance of bite cells. 

Other features of the peripheral smear include anisocytes, polychromatic cells, and poikilocytes with unevenly distributed hemoglobin (hemighosts).

Other options:

Option A: Mutations in the genes coding for ankyrin, spectrin, and band proteins are responsible for hereditary spherocytosis (HS). It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by poor interaction between the mutated RBC membrane proteins. This leads to the loss of membrane fragments relative to the cytoplasm, thereby causing the RBC to assume the least possible diameter for a given volume. Peripheral smear shows characteristic spherocytes that appear dark, with no central pallor. Howell- Jolly bodies can also be seen.

A slide showing spherocytes in peripheral smear:



Option B: Acquired mutation of PIGA gene is responsible for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). This condition causes complement-mediated destruction of RBCs due to the absence/ impaired production of membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins CD59 and CD55. PNH is characterized by a triad of hemolysis, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis. The peripheral smear reveals RBCs that are usually normo-macrocytic but may become microcytic due to chronic iron loss through hemoglobinuria.

Option C: Point mutation in the beta-globin gene is responsible for sickle cell anemia. This autosomal recessive disorder is characterized by the polymerization of the abnormal HbS hemoglobin during conditions of low oxygen tension (acidosis, hypoxia) which leads to sickling of the red blood cell, hemolysis, and microvascular obstruction (may lead to vaso-occlusive crises and autosplenectomy). Peripheral smear findings reveal sickled RBCs, reticulocytosis, and Howell-Jolly bodies (small nuclear remnants in RBCs that are usually removed by a functional spleen).

questions.text: 14. Which of the following diseases follows the inheritance pattern as shown by the pedigree analysis given below?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome follows the inheritance pattern as shown by the pedigree analysis.

The pedigree analysis shows an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance. Points in favour of X-linked dominant inheritance:

* Females are affected twice as often as males.

* Affected females show a 50% probability of transmitting the disease to their son or daughter.

* The affected male transmits the disease to all his daughters and none of his sons.



Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. 

Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anteriorlenticonus, macularflecks, and cornealdystrophy.

Other Options:

Option A: Tay-Sach’s disease follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.

Option B: Huntington’s disease follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Option C: Fabry’s disease follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

questions.text: 15. A middle-aged woman undergoes an endoscopy for epigastric pain. A small nodule is found in the wall of the stomach. Biopsy reveals well-formed pancreatic acini and ducts, with no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. Which of the following best describes this lesion?
questions.solution:
The lesion in this scenario is best described as a choristoma.

Heterotopia, also known as choristoma, refers to the presence of microscopically normal cells or tissues in an unusual location. Typically, these heterotopic rests are insignificant; however, they may be clinically mistaken for neoplasms.

For example, pancreatic tissue may be found in the wall of the stomach or small intestine, or a small cluster of adrenal cells could be located in the kidneys, lungs, or ovaries. 

In rare instances, true neoplasms can originate in unexpected locations, leading to unusual presentations, such as an adrenal carcinoma developing in the ovary.

Other Options

Option A: Hamartoma- Disorganized but benign proliferation of normal tissue elements native to that organ. E.g., Pulmonary hamartoma (cartilage, bronchial epithelium).

Option C: Teratoma- Tumor containing tissue from more than one germ cell layer (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm). E.g., Ovarian teratoma with hair, teeth, neural tissue.

Option D: Heteroplasia- Replacement of one differentiated tissue type by another differentiated type, not normally present. E.g., Osseous metaplasia, cartilage formation in scar.

questions.text: 17. Warm antibody immunohemolytic anaemia commonly involves:
questions.solution:
Warm antibody type is the most common form of immune hemolytic anaemia, with IgG antibodies being the primary cause and IgA antibodies less commonly involved.

Approximately 50% of cases are idiopathic (primary), and red cell hemolysis primarily occurs extravascularly. When red blood cells are coated with IgG, they bind to Fc receptors on phagocytes. Partial membrane removal during this interaction produces spherocytes, which are later eliminated by splenic macrophages.

 Moderate splenomegaly is a common observation. In many instances, the antibodies target Rh blood group antigens.

Autoimmune hemolytic anemias (AIHA) cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis.

In the warm antibody type, hemolysis is extravascular. IgG-coated red cells are phagocytosed and destroyed in the spleen.

In cold agglutinin type, hemolysis is extravascular and intravascular. In the peripheral vascular bed (low temperature), IgM binds to the red cells. This causes agglutination and complement-fixing. They are unbound when they reach the general circulation. However, the IgM interaction causes deposition of sublytic quantities of C3b. It is an excellent opsonin, which leads to the removal of RBCs by phagocytes in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow.

Cold hemolysin type is a rare subtype of AIHA. Hemolysis is intravascular. IgG binds to the P blood group antigen on the red cells, which leads to complement-mediated lysis.

questions.solution:
CD5 is present only in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and not in follicular lymphoma.

Neoplastic cells in follicular lymphoma closely resemble normal germinal centre B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface Ig, and BCL6. It is managed with the R-CHOP regimen.

CLL presents in the elderly and presents with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphocytosis. It's diagnosed by flow cytometry and managed by BTK inhibitors like Ibrutinib. The gold standard for therapy is a combination of fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab.

Serum ferritin: 10 μg/L  TIBC: elevated Serum iron: low Percent transferrin saturation: 19% Peripheral blood smear- normal blood picture with a few scattered microcytic RBCs

The given patient with decreased Serum Iron, raised TIBC, low transferrin saturation and a normal blood picture with few scattered microcytes is probably in the stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis. 

The progression to Iron deficiency anemia occurs in three stages-

* Stage of Negative iron balance: Usually results from mechanisms like blood loss, pregnancy, growth spurts in adolescence or inadequate dietary intake of iron. During this period, iron stores—reflected by the serum ferritin level decrease. Under such circumstances, the iron stores from the reticuloendothelial sites are mobilized. 

* Stage of Iron deficient erythropoesis- Once the stores are exhausted, the serum iron levels begin declining and, TIBC and RBC protoporphyrin increase. Hemoglobin synthesis remains normal as long as serum iron levels are within the normal range, even with decreasing iron stores. However, once transferrin saturation drops to 15–20%, hemoglobin synthesis is negatively impacted.

* Stage of iron deficiency Anemia: Eventually the Hemoglobin level starts to fall and the RBCs become microcytic hypochromic resulting in the typical blood picture of Iron deficiency anemia. Poikilocytosis in the form of small, pencil-shaped RBCs is also seen characteristically.

questions.text: 27. An elderly woman came to the OPD with a pigmented lesion on her face. The histopathology of the excisional biopsy is shown below. Which of the following stains can be used to visualise the pigment found in this histopathological specimen?
questions.solution:
The pigment shown in the histopathological specimen is melanin. Masson Fontana can be used to stain melanin.

The clinical scenario and the histopathology are suggestive of melanoma. The pigment shown in the histopathology image is melanin.

Melanin is an endogenous brown-black pigment produced in melanocytes. Its formation occurs when the enzyme tyrosinase catalyzes the conversion of tyrosine into dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). 

Melanin is a pigment found in hair, skin, the retina, iris, and specific regions of the central nervous system (as neuromelanin). Its pathological presence can be observed in skin tumors such as melanomas.

Stains used for melanin:

Masson Fontana silver stain: It is an ammoniacal silver stain that stains melanin black. It also stains argentaffin granules, which are normally found in duodenal mucosa endocrine cells and are pathologically associated with carcinoid syndromes.

DOPA-oxidase method: It is considered the most specific histochemical technique for detecting melanin. Melanocytes contain tyrosinase (DOPA-oxidase activity), which catalyzes the oxidation of dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

This reaction produces a brownish-black deposit at the site of melanin production. It helps to distinguish melanotic tumors(melanoma) from amelanotic or other non-melanocytic tumors.

Schmorl’s method: Stains melanin blue-green.

questions.text: 28. A leukocyte is rolling along the endothelium when it detects a site of inflammation. It traverses through the endothelial cell, exits the blood vessel and into the extracellular matrix, mediated by the PECAM-1 molecule. What is this process called?
questions.solution:
Diapedesis is the movement of leukocytes through the intact endothelium of the capillaries to reach the site of injury. This process is aided by platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1).

Diapedesis occurs through the interendothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions, such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31. 

The process of acute inflammation has 3 components: An increase in blood flow due to small vessel dilation, and increased permeability of the microvasculature to aid plasma proteins and leukocytes to leave the circulation and migrate to the site of injury to exert their effects. The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury involves the following steps:

Margination and rolling: Leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface because of stasis of blood flow and start rolling on the vessel wall because of signaling molecules from the endothelium, mediated by E-Selectin, P-Selectin, Glycam-1, and CD34.

Adhesion: Leukocytes are attached to the endothelium because of adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. Mediated by: ICAM-1, VCAM-1.

Diapedesis/Transmigration: of the leukocytes across the vascular endothelium. Mediated by: PECAM-1.

Migration: towards a chemotactic stimulus in the extravascular tissues. Chemotactic/Inflammatory factors mediating this process: C5a, IL-8, LTB4, Kallikrein, PAF. (Options A, B and D)

Selectins, integrins, and their ligands are the most important proteins involved in adhesion and migration. Selectins are of 3 types: L-selectin present on leukocytes, E-selectin present on endothelium, and P-selectin present in platelets and on the endothelium. 

The weak rolling action slows down the leukocytes and allows them to bind more firmly to the endothelium with the help of integrins. Chemokines that are produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leukocytes and activate them.

This in turn converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4, and LFA-1 present on the leukocytes to a high-affinity state. This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leukocytes leads to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.

questions.text: 29. A 46-year-old man presents with fever, lethargy, progressive sensorymotor polyneuropathy, back pain, and loss of libido. On examination,you notice generalised skin hyperpigmentation and hepatomegaly,splenomegaly and gynecomastia are present. Radiological imaging shows sclerotic bone lesions. Histopathological picture of the bone-marrow aspirate is given below. What can be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The HPE image and the clinical features are suggestive of POEMS Syndrome. The image shows malignant plasma cells with a Mott cell, a plasma cell with intracytoplasmic Russell bodies (an eosinophilic, uniformly staining membrane-bound body which contains immunoglobulin).

POEMS (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal gammopathy, and skin changes) syndrome is a rare paraneoplastic condition associated with a plasma-cell dyscrasia.

For diagnosis, all of the following four criteria must be met:

* Any one of the following:

* Extravascular volume overload (edema, pleural effusion, or ascites),

* Endocrinopathy (adrenal, thyroid, pituitary, gonadal, parathyroid, and pancreatic),

* Skin changes (hyperpigmentation, hypertrichosis, glomeruloid hemangiomata, plethora, acrocyanosis, flushing, and white nails)

* Thrombocytosis/polycythemia

Option C: Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a malignancy of lymphoplasmacytoid cells that secrete IgM. It is also associated with lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly, but the major clinical manifestation is hyperviscosity syndrome.

questions.text: 30. A curious medical student wants to study injured cells in a light microscope. What is the most important light microscopic feature he would notice in this type of cell injury?

choices.text: Nuclear changes like Pyknosis and Karyolysis

questions.solution:
Nuclear changes like pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis are the features of irreversible cell injury that are visible on light microscopy. All other changes mentioned are ultrastructural findings visible only on electron microscopy.

Irreversible Cell Injury:

* Nuclear Changes: Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis.

* Electron Microscopy Features:

* Discontinuities in plasma and organelle membranes.

* Marked dilation of mitochondria with large amorphous densities.

* Intracytoplasmic myelin figures.

* Amorphous debris.

* Aggregates of fluffy material (denatured protein).

Reversible Cell Injury:

* Cellular Swelling: (Earliest change) Occurs due to ATP depletion leading to sodium-potassium pump failure, causing sodium and water accumulation within the cell.

* Fatty Change: Observed in cells actively involved in or dependent on fat metabolism, such as liver hepatocytes and myocardial cells.

* Light Microscopy: No noticeable changes.

* Ultrastructural Findings (Electron Microscopy):

* Mitochondrial swelling and small amorphous densities.

* Plasma membrane blebs and loss of microvilli.

* Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).

* Detachment of ribosomes from the granular ER.

* Nuclear changes, including disaggregation of granular and fibrillar filaments.

Important Note: Mitochondrial amorphous floccular densities are the most crucial morphological indicator of irreversible cell injury; however, these are not visible with a light microscope.

questions.text: 31. A 40-year-old male with a chronic transfusion history presents with acanthocytosis and progressive muscle weakness. Hematological workup reveals the absence of a specific red cell antigen associated with the Kell system. Which phenotype is most likely present in this person?
questions.solution:
The most likely phenotype is the McLeod phenotype.

The Kell protein is a large protein composed of 720 amino acids, and its secondary structure contains numerous antigenic epitopes. The immunogenicity of the Kell system is third behind the ABO and Rh systems.

The McLeod phenotype is a rare condition associated with the absence of the Kell precursor protein, which is encoded by a gene located on the X chromosome. It manifests with acanthocytosis, shortened red blood cell (RBC) survival, and a progressive muscular dystrophy that includes cardiac issues.

Other Options

Option A: Fy(a-b-) phenotype is Duffy negative phenotype, which is protective against Plasmodium vivax.

Option C: Bombay phenotype is when the H antigen is absent from the RBCs.

Option D: A Lewis-negative phenotype is not clinically significant and is common during pregnancy. It is not affected by alloimmunisation.

questions.text: 32. A middle-aged man was recently started on DOTS regimen. If the patient does not take pyridoxine concomitantly, which of the following abnormalities can be expected in his investigations?

choices.text: Ring sideroblasts in bone marrow aspirate

questions.solution:
Ring sideroblasts in bone marrow aspirate are the investigation abnormality that can be expected in a patient who fails to take pyridoxine along with the DOTS regimen. 

DOTS regimen is used to treat tuberculosis. It contains isoniazid which is implicated in interfering with vitamin B6 metabolism and leads to impaired heme synthesis. This causes ineffective erythropoiesis as well as retention of the iron within the mitochondria of erythroblasts. This retention can be seen, in bone marrow aspirates, in the form of nucleated red cells with iron granules distributed around the nucleus. This morphology is termed ringed sideroblasts and they are characteristic of sideroblastic anemia (shown below).



Peripheral smear in sideroblastic anemia would show classic erythrocyte dimorphism (microcytic RBCs intermixed with normal red cell population). MCV would also be decreased. Even though there is ineffective erythropoiesis, the iron overload causes an increase in serum iron concentration and a normal TIBC level. 

Sideroblastic anemia caused by isoniazid is reversible upon the stoppage of the drug.

Other medications that can lead to the reversible type of this anemia include:

* pyrazinamide

* cycloserine

* chloramphenicol

* alcohol

It can also be seen in myelodysplastic syndrome. Sideroblastic anemia can also be congenital. The congenital type is passed down via X-linked or an autosomal recessive pattern.

Other options: 

Option A: Heinz bodies are red cell inclusion bodies that are seen in glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

questions.text:
33. A 50 year old man presents to you with intense pruritus, yellowing of the abdomen, palms, soles and sclera. One year ago, the patient received a liver transplant due to a diagnosis of hepatocellular cancer. Lab reports are shown below. Biopsy performed is as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Total Bilirubin - 30mg/dl Direct Bilirubin - 26mg/dl Alkaline Phosphatase(ALP) - 450 U/L GGT - 20 U/L, AST - 25U/L, ALT - 35U/L
questions.solution:
This patient exhibiting a cholestatic pattern of jaundice, accompanied by ductopenia as observed in the biopsy, and having undergone a liver transplant one year ago, may be diagnosed with vanishing bile duct syndrome.

Chronic rejection is characterized by the presence of focal parenchymal necrosis, mononuclear cell infiltration, progressive cholestasis, and fibrosis. In some patients, this process will lead to the loss of intrahepatic bile ducts, which is called vanishing bile duct syndrome. 

Vanishing Bile Duct Syndrome (VBDS) is characterized by cholestasis and ductopenia, caused by immune issues, infections, medications, or ischemia. Bile duct degeneration occurs over months or years. Acute/subacute forms, progressing over months, show less ductular reaction and portal fibrosis, with more prominent acute cholestasis, as seen in allograft rejection, severe GVHD, certain medications, and treated Hodgkin lymphoma.

Chronic transplant rejection (months to years post-transplant) involves both cellular and humoral immunity (Type II and IV hypersensitivity). Recipient CD4+ T cells reacting to donor peptides presented by recipient APCs (including allogeneic MHC) cause cytokine secretion, leading to vascular smooth muscle proliferation, parenchymal atrophy, and interstitial fibrosis. This manifests as bronchiolitis obliterans (pulmonary), accelerated atherosclerosis (cardiovascular), graft nephropathy (renal), and vanishing bile duct syndrome (hepatic).

Other options

 Option A: Primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, and steatorrhea similar to PBC. It is more common in men in the 3-5th decade. It is characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis of intra and extrahepatic ducts. The perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA), is positive and anti-mitochondrial antibodies is negative. Liver biopsy shows concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis.



Option B: Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. Pathological features include emperipolesis, interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis and rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.



Option D: Biopsy of the specimen shows ductopenia and mononuclear cell infiltration. Laboratory reports also suggest a cholestatic pattern of jaundice, thus making the diagnosis of a recurrence of hepatocellular carcinoma less likely.

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

* Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient

* Histopathological findings:

* Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas

* Neutrophils accumulate

* Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

* Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  

* Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.

* Histopathological findings:

* Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury

* Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)

* Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 

* Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure

* Histopathological findings:

* Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.

* Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.

* Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

* Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.

* Histopathological findings:

* Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)

* Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane

* Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: 34. A 10-year-old boy presents with difficulty climbing stairs, walking long distances, worsening handwriting, clumsiness, and mumbled speech. Examination reveals pes cavus, depressed deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar reflexes. Spinal X-ray and an echocardiogram showing an enlarged heart are also noted. What trinucleotide repeat is associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features showing progressive ataxia, dysarthria, clumsiness, depressed deep tendon reflexes, pes cavus, cardiomyopathy and x-ray showing scoliosis are highly suggestive of Friedreich ataxia. It is caused by an expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat related to chromosome 9q13.

It is an autosomal-recessive disease with progressive ataxia, spasticity, weakness, sensory neuropathy, and cardiomyopathy. Deep tendon reflexes are depressed or absent, but an extensor plantar reflex is typically present.

The expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat on chromosome 9q13, encodes frataxin, a protein found in the mitochondrial inner membrane where it is involved in the assembly of iron-sulfur cluster enzymes of complex I and II. Affected individuals have extremely low levels of protein.

Patients become wheelchair-bound within 5 years of onset and the life expectancy is up to 40-50 years of age. Cardiomyopathy is associated with arrhythmias and congestive heart failure which eventually contributes to the affected individual's death

questions.text: 35. Which of the following is false about RB as the governor of cell cycle?

choices.text: The function of RB protein is to regulate at the G1-S checkpoint
Hypophosphorylated state of the RB promote cell cycle progression
Active RB binds and inhibits the E2F family of transcription factors preventing transcription of cyclin E

questions.solution:
Hyperphosphorylated state (inactive) of RB protein promotes cell cycle progression.

RB, called the Governor of Proliferation is a key negative regulator of the G1/S cell cycle transition and is directly or indirectly inactivated in most human cancers.

* The normal RB gene is present on chromosome 13q14.

* RB -  active hypophosphorylated state in quiescent cells and an inactive hyperphosphorylated state in cells passing through the G1/S cell cycle transition.

* Cyclin D/CDK-4 phosphorylates RB inactivating the protein, and releases E2F to induce target genes such as cyclin E.

* RB -  antiproliferative effects by binding and inhibiting E2F transcription factors, thereby preventing transcription of cyclin E, required for cells to pass through the G1-S phase cell cycle checkpoint.

* The antiproliferative effect of RB is abrogated in cancers through a variety of mechanisms, including:

* Loss-of-function mutations affecting RB

* Gene amplification of CDK4 and cyclin D genes

* Loss of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors (p16/INK4a)

* Viral oncoproteins that bind and inhibit RB (E7 protein of HPV)

Loss-of-function mutations of the RB gene are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, a subset of glioblastomas, small-cell carcinomas of the lung, breast cancers, and bladder carcinomas.

38. A patient after a kidney transplant was diagnosed with an infection from cytomegalovirus (CMV). This virus encodes certain important proteins that inhibit caspases, thus hampering important mechanisms of host defense. In this situation, a form of 'cell death' which acts as a backup mechanism in host defense is ______

* Morphologically same as necrosis and biochemically same as apoptosis.

* Mechanistically same as necrosis because it is caspase-independent.

* Mechanistically same as apoptosis but it is caspase-independent.

* Both morphologically and mechanistically same as apoptosis and it is caspase-dependent.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of necroptosis. It is mechanistically the same as apoptosis but it is caspase-independent.

In a CMV infected cell, caspases are inhibited hence apoptosis is not working. In that case, a form of cell death which serves as a back up mechanism should be caspase-independant which is necroptossis.

questions.text: 40. A 2-year-old boy presents with recurrent diarrhea, eczema, and failure to thrive. Mutations in the transcription factors of the regulatory T lymphocytes result in this condition.

The classic presentation of IPEX is a triad of:

* Failure to thrive with severe chronic diarrhea due to an autoimmune enteropathy

* Autoimmune endocrinopathy (neonatal type 1 diabetes or thyroiditis)

* Dermatitis (usually eczematous)

questions.text: 41. A 55-year-old man presented with lethargy, weight loss, and massive splenomegaly. Investigations revealed pancytopenia. A hematological malignancy was suspected. A peripheral smear showed cells positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase. On flow cytometry, these cells were found to express CD 11c and CD 103. What is the cell of origin of his condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with massive splenomegaly, tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase positive cells on his blood smear, and tumor cells with CD11c and CD 103 positive most likely has a diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia. The cell of origin of hairy cell leukemia is the post germinal memory B cell. 

Hairy cell leukemia is a distinctive B cell neoplasm, that predominantly affects middle-aged males. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase is the cytochemical stain characteristically shown by leukemic hairy cells. These cells are called so because of the fine hair-like projections on their surface as shown below. On peripheral blood smear, hairy cells have round or reniform nuclei and moderate amounts of pale blue cytoplasm with thread or bleb like an extension. In the bone marrow, these cells are usually trapped in a mesh of reticulin fibers and so it is difficult to aspirate and hence termed a dry tap. 

The classic hairy cells can be seen in the slide is shown below:



The cells in hairy cell leukemia express the usual B-cell markers- CD-19 and 20, but they also express certain more specific markers such as CD 11c, CD 25, CD103, and annexin A1

Patients commonly present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration of the leukemic cells. Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement can also be seen. There can be an atypical monocytopenia due to which these patients experience an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF (B-type Raf proto-oncogene) inhibitors, and they have an excellent prognosis.

Option A: Naive B cell is the cell of origin of mantle cell lymphoma.

Option C: Germinal center B cell is the cell of origin in follicular lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, and diffuse large B- cell lymphoma.

Option D: Precursor B cell is the cell of origin of B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

questions.text: 42. Which of the following features is false regarding cytotoxic T-cells and natural killer cells?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cells are MHC l restricted cells
Both are effective against virus-infected cells
Both require priming by antibodies to be activated
Natural killer cells is antigen non-specific

questions.solution:
The false statement is C. Natural killer (NK) cells do not require priming while cytotoxic T cells require priming with antigens for action since they are a part of cellular immunity. 

NK cells have different mechanisms of action while killing target cells. They can lyse IgG-coated target cells by binding to the Fc tail of IgG, through the CD16 receptor expressed on NK cells. This phenomenon is known as antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).

NK cells secrete various cytokines such as interferon-γ (IFN-γ), which activate macrophages to destroy ingested microbes.

Target cell destruction by NK cells is also mediated through two others receptors - activating receptors and inhibitory receptors.

The activating receptors enable NK cells to recognize infected and stressed cells. The inhibitory receptors recognize self class-I MHC molecules, that are expressed on all healthy cells thereby preventing NK cells from killing normal cells. Virus infection / neoplastic transformation overexpresses the activating receptors and simultaneously reduces the expression of class-I MHC molecules. As a result, NK cells are activated and the infected cells are killed.

CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes directly kill damaged cells.

questions.text: 43. A 52-year-old female patient who’s diagnosed with breast cancer comes with complaints of fatigue, weakness and shortness of breath. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. On bone marrow biopsy shows marrow fibrosis. What is the most likely peripheral blood smear (PBS) picture seen in this condition?

choices.text: Leucoerythroblastosis with nucleated RBC and tear-drop cells

questions.solution:
The most likely peripheral blood smear for the given clinical scenario is a leucoerythroblastosis with nucleated RBC and teardrop cells.

Myelophthisic anemia is a type of marrow failure characterized by the replacement of normal bone marrow components by space-occupying lesions. Metastatic cancer is the most frequent cause, typically originating from carcinomas of the breast, lung, and prostate.

Bone marrow infiltration leads to fibrosis, disrupting the normal release of RBCs and WBCs. This causes a leukoerythroblastic picture: premature nucleated erythroid and immature granulocytic forms, plus dacrocytes. Extramedullary hematopoiesis in the liver and spleen results in hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. 

The image shows this blood picture with nucleated RBCs, tear-drop cells, and immature myeloid cells.



Other Options:

Option B: Normochromic anemia with hairy cells is seen in hairy cell leukemia. Peripheral smear shows small lymphoid cells with abundant cytoplasm and characteristic “hairy” projections

Option C: Normochromic anemia with spherocytes is the PBS finding in autoimmune hemolytic anemia and hereditary spherocytosis. Spherocytosis is associated with hypercellular marrow.

Option D: Leukocytosis with basophilia is seen in CML, chronic myeloid leukaemia, which is a clonal myeloproliferative neoplasm caused by the BCR-ABL fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome). It also presents with leukocytosis and a left-shifted differential count with basophilia.

questions.text: 46. All of the following statements are true regarding the fixation technique used for the fixation of fats in the histopathological examination by frozen section technique except:

choices.text: The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain
The tissues that contain more fat will need to be cut at a higher temperature
The majority of the tissue can be appropriately sectioned between -15⁰C to -25⁰C
Fixatives containing alcohols will remove lipids

questions.solution:
The fixation technique used for the fixation of fats in a histopathological examination is the frozen section. The tissues that contain more fat will need to be cut at a lower temperature and not a higher temperature.

Frozen section :

A frozen section ensures that the tissue does not go through routine processing, which can remove the lipids. When the tissue sample goes through rapid freezing, it becomes firmer. The ice acts as an embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned. The temperature range in the cryostat machine usually ranges from 0⁰C to -35⁰C. The majority of the tissue can be appropriately sectioned between -15⁰C to -25⁰C. Tissue samples that contain water can be sectioned at a higher temperature. The tissues that contain more fat will need to be cut at a lower temperature.

The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain. It can identify neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues. It is used in the following conditions:

* Fat emboli in lung tissue

* Renal cell carcinoma

* Sebaceous gland tumors of the skin

* Lipid-rich carcinomas

Fixatives containing alcohols, or routine processing with clearing, will remove lipids. Fixation can be achieved by the following methods:

questions.text: 47. Which of the following is not a part of WHO's major criteria for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with panmyelosis

questions.solution:
Subnormal serum erythropoietin level is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera. The other three options are included as major criteria for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera.

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which there is an accumulation of phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets in the absence of a recognizable physiologic stimulus. It is the most common myeloproliferative neoplasm. The increase in the red cells is predominantly responsible for the clinical symptoms in this condition.

In 15% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years, there is increased myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients.

The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. 

Clinical features of PCV:

* Splenomegaly

* Thrombocytosis - leads to venous arterial thrombosis, hepatic venous thrombosis. Erythromelalgia is the erythema, burning, and pain in the extremities. It also occurs due to thrombocytosis.

* Erythrocytosis - leads to hyperviscosity, leading to neurologic symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances, transient ischemic attacks (TIA), and systolic hypertension. 

* Aquagenic pruritis

* Hyperuricemia and gout - It may occur due to the large turnover of the hematopoietic stem cells

Diagnosis: Criteria for diagnosis is given below:

Major criteria:

* Hb more than 16.5g/dL in males and 16g/dL in females or hematocrit of >49% in men and >48% in women

* Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis) including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation.

* Presence of JAK-2 mutation

Minor criteria:

* Subnormal erythropoietin levels.

Diagnosis requires all three major criteria or the first 2 major and 1 minor criterion.

Management:

* Target Hb levels are < 14g/dL in males and < 12g/dL in females.

* Periodic phlebotomy can be done to reduce hyperviscosity and to maintain the red cell mass. It is usually done at 3-month intervals.

* Anticoagulants are given when there is thrombosis.

* Allopurinol can be given to control hyperuricemia.

* Ruxolitinib which is a nonspecific JAK2 inhibitor, pegylated IFN-α, or PUVA therapy can be used for intractable pruritis.

* Ruxolitinib or pegylated IFN-α can be used to manage symptomatic splenomegaly.

* Anagrelide which is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor is used to reduce platelet count in these patients.

The given clinical presentation of an HIV+ individual with raised purplish spots involving skin and oral cavity, with the biopsy image showing sheets of whorled spindle cells along with prominent erythrocyte extravasation within slit-like spaces, is suggestive of Kaposi Sarcoma, which is caused by HHV8.

Infection by HHV8 leads to the production of several proteins that have a potential role in stimulating spindle cells.  Although HHV8 infection is necessary for KS development, its mere presence is not enough and usually needs an additional cofactor for disease manifestation, which in this case is HIV positivity. HIV-mediated immunosuppression aids in the dissemination of HHV8. 

Primary effusion lymphoma and Castleman disease - HHV8 infects both endothelial and lymphoid cells. Thus, it is also linked with rare B-cell lymphomas in AIDS patients, called Primary effusion lymphoma (such as Primary CNS lymphoma) and with Multicentric Castleman disease- a B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder. Primary effusion lymphoma shows co-infection by both HHV8 and EBV and is thus an example of unusual co-operativity between two oncogenic viruses. 

Other Options:

Option 3: Hodgkin's lymphoma: is a group of lymphoid neoplasms that have been associated with EBV. It is thought that LMP-1 protein expressed by EBV+ tumor cells results in upregulation of the NF-KB pathway. The distinctive morphological feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.



Option 4: Oral Hairy Leukoplakia: Caused by EBV; usually presents in immunocompromised individuals as a white corrugated plaque on the lateral border of the tongue that can't be rubbed off. The Epstein-Barr virus replicates in maturing epithelial cells but not in basal or parabasal keratinocytes. On microscopy, the upper spinous layer shows the characteristic hyper parakeratosis and acanthosis with balloon cells



Option 5: Infectious mononucleosis: usually presents with fever, sore throat, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly in late adolescent and young adults. The peripheral smear shows atypical lymphocytes called as Downey cells which are CD8+ T cells.

questions.text: 49. Which of the following is the most likely consequence seen in somatic cells because of inactive telomerase?
questions.solution:
The most likely consequence of inactive telomerase in somatic cells is that somatic cells experience accelerated aging and a decline in function.

Telomeres, composed of short TG-rich repeated DNA sequences found at the ends of eukaryotic chromosomes, serve a crucial role in chromosome replication and protection. Despite not encoding proteins (Option C), telomeres prevent replicative senescence, a process where chromosomes progressively shorten with each cell division until a critical point, triggering cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis.

Telomerase, an enzyme utilizing its RNA template to add nucleotides to chromosome ends. The activity of this enzyme is absent in somatic cells but present in germ cells. This absence in somatic cells contributes to accelerated aging and functional decline, as shortened telomeres result in cell-cycle exit, hindering the generation of new cells for tissue repair.

In the absence of telomerase, somatic cells experience replicative senescence, a phenomenon where cells cease dividing, leading to an inability to replace damaged cells. Conversely, abnormal telomerase reactivation in somatic cells allows evasion of senescence and apoptosis, enabling cells to undergo several additional divisions.

In cancer cells, telomerase is typically reactivated, stabilizing telomere length and facilitating indefinite proliferation (Options A & D). Inability to undergo cell division cannot be considered as the most likely consequence of telomerase inactivity, as telomerases are not directly responsible for cell division, they are only responsible for maintaining chromosomal structural integrity.

questions.text:
50. A 3-year-old child presented with complaints of recurrent respiratory infections, skin purpura, and eczema. She is currently undergoing evaluation for Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Which immunoglobulins are elevated in this condition?

* IgA

* IgM

* IgG

* IgE

* IgD
questions.solution:
The immunoglobulins elevated in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome are IgA and IgE (option B).

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by thrombocytopenia (resulting in bleeding diathesis such as skin purpura), eczema, and recurrent infections. It is caused by a mutation in the gene located at Xp11.23, which encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

The disease is characterized by low serum IgM levels. The serum IgG levels are usually normal. The levels of IgA and IgE are elevated. Patients are at an increased risk for B-cell lymphomas.

The thymus appears normal in the early course of the disease, but there is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and the T-cell zones (paracortical areas) of the lymph nodes, resulting in variable defects in cellular immunity.
